race.name: Spring Thaw
race.tagline: Early-season Michigan gravel when the roads are still thawing near Muskegon.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Michigan countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Michigan event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Spring Thaw is a local event in Michigan—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Michigan countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Michigan gravel race. Worth it for Michigan/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Michigan—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan races: Barry-Roubaix, Iceman Cometh.

logistics.food: Muskegon has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Michigan rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Muskegon is accessible via decent highways with Grand Rapids airport proximity for regional travel. Spring Thaw events handle basic setup well - ThePsion helped volunteers "setting up coolers of hot chocolate, roaster pans full of soups" at Pittsburgh.

length.explanation: 50 miles sits awkwardly between casual and serious distances. Ray George's report shows the group "naturally broke into smaller packs" early on climbs, suggesting riders of varying abilities find different comfort levels with the distance and terrain demands. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Spring Thaw courses emphasize accessibility over challenge. Minnesota's version notes "All bikes are welcome" with "gravel and paved roadways" while Ohio's Scioto Trail "drains well" providing manageable conditions even in wet weather.

elevation.explanation: 2000 feet over 50 miles is gentle rolling - 40 feet per mile average. Michigan doesn't offer massive climbs, so this fits the geography. Enough to feel it in your legs but won't destroy anyone accustomed to actual hills. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Spring conditions create variable weather challenges. Pittsburgh's event had "parts of the course were more windy than others" with "one weird spot where it was always drizzling." Ohio's 2025 edition started with "rainy conditions" requiring shelter time. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Lake Michigan proximity means sea-level racing with zero altitude considerations. No acclimatization needed - fitness translates directly to performance without elevation variables affecting pacing or recovery strategies. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Michigan gravel offers modest adventure potential with forest roads and lake country scenery. 50 miles provides enough distance for some solitude and suffering. The real adventure here is trying to locate an event that doesn't appear in any official results or registrations.

prestige.explanation: The "10th Annual Great Big Spring Thaw Ride" drew "25+ show up for a rainy start" with local sponsor support from Brioso Coffee and The Bread Pirate Roberts. Kenda surprised participants with free tires or tubes, reflecting grassroots community character over prestige branding.

race_quality.explanation: Organization varies with some operational gaps. Pittsburgh lacked proper pace groups - "There was no 10:30 pacer, so a bunch of us put ourselves between 10 and 11." However, volunteer support and post-race amenities provide adequate infrastructure.

experience.explanation: Muskegon has decent terrain potential near Lake Michigan, but with no confirmed course details or rider reports, you're flying blind. Could be great, could be a disaster.

community.explanation: Muskegon cycling community exists and is reasonably active, though nothing like the established scenes in Grand Rapids or Ann Arbor. Michigan gravel riders are generally solid people who show up and suffer together. The challenge is finding this actual event to participate with them.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-200 riders, no field data exists because no confirmed race exists. Michigan has strong gravel talent that migrates to known events like Barry-Roubaix and Iceman, but they're not showing up to phantom races. Expect small local turnout at best. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: If this race actually exists, Michigan events typically offer solid value with reasonable entry fees and decent post-race spreads. The region doesn't gouge like Colorado or California events. Problem is paying for something that might not be real.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Organizers provided waterproof route maps and Kenda contributed tires or tubes to participants, reducing rider equipment costs. The community sponsor involvement from local businesses like Brioso Coffee suggests reasonable regional pricing without resort town premiums. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Home Depot Fights Shoplifting With New Technology
videos.description: The outbreak of brazen smash-and-grab robberies and shoplifting is showing no signs of stopping, but some stores are taking extreme measures to stop would-be thieves in their tracks, including Home Depot. Spokesperson Christina Cornell gave Inside Edition an exclusive look at the company's latest crime-fighting technology, including a shopping cart with wheels that lock if you don't pay and bluetooth-activated items.

videos.title: Flooding, Muskegon River, Evart, Michigan  - REAL USA Ep. 94
videos.description:
We've returned to the banks of the Muskegon River a week after our initial video on the spring ice melt, and the flooding we had hoped would be avoided is happening anyway. Michigan had record level snow fall this past winter, and as the snow melts and spring rains start the saturated ground can't hold any more. Water levels are reaching some of the highest in local residents' memory, and possibly in recorded history. 

Donate to The REAL United States Video Blog: 
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=VFFB7P269QV3N

Stay connected!
Facebook Page: http://www.facebook.com/RealUnitedStates
Twitter: https://twitter.com/REALUSvlog
Google+ https://plus.google.com/u/0/b/112052358926074194091/112052358926074194091/posts
Text updates on your mobile phone: http://motube.us/realunitedstatesvlog
Website: http://www.realunitedstaes.com
See (most) all video locations marked on Google Maps: http://bit.ly/VzTI9k

EXACT LOCATION of video:
Latitude: 43.89544
Longitude: -85.25925

videos.title: Colorado Springs Firefighters Help Make Cancer Patient's Wish Come True
videos.description: The Colorado Springs Fire Department helped fulfill a young girl's Make-A-Wish wish by filling up a swim spa on Saturday.
videos.transcript:
well the Colorado Springs Fire
Department helped make a wish come true
for a young patient Lane is one of 50
people diagnosed with a rare cellular
disease make-a-wish Colorado answered
her wish for a swim spa they say she
loves to swim so the Colorado Springs
Fire Department helped deliver that spa
and fill it up Lane didn't get to take a
dip because it takes a couple of hours
to warm up oh but some neighborhood kids
they got right in

videos.title: Zeeland West senior Owen Telgenhof recovers from serious brain injury at Mary Free Bed
videos.description: Owen Telgenhof speaks about his recovery at Mary Free Bed in Grand Rapids on Thursday, March 2, 2023. Owen, who is a senior at Zeeland West, is recovering from a serious brain injury after he pulled out in front of a loaded gravel truck in Zeeland on Oct. 20, 2022. (Cory Morse | MLive.com)
videos.transcript:
I had to relearn how to walk how to talk
uh

keep his spirits up we have a lot of

which is all for all of it so yeah
we appreciate it
you never realize
until this happens but it's tough

videos.title: Plenty of salt, money left for Kent County roads
videos.description: The last few weeks have delivered a blast of winter weather to remember. Challenging road conditions and days of schools closures meant that many people simply stayed indoors, but there was no rest for road crews. (Feb. 15, 2019)
videos.transcript:
EMILY:..OVER THE LAST THREE
WEEKS, WEST MICHIGAN HAS BEEN
SOCKED WITH EXTREME WINTER
WEATHER.EVERYTHING FROM
SUB-ZERO TEMPERATURES TO
FREEZING RAIN AND LOTS AND
LOTS OF SNOW.THE ROAD CREWS
